I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will serve as a facility for the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) to respond expeditiously and efficiently to support the knowledge needs 
of Asia and the Pacific region (particularly East Asia) by developing strategic knowledge products 
focusing on policy development and policy advisory support.1 Knowledge and advisory products 
will be developed in core sectors where ADB has lending operations and other essential areas 
where there is a demand and/or potential for ADB strategic policy assistance, and where ADB 
exhibits a comparative advantage. The policy development work under the TA may serve as 
inputs to overall policymaking and coordination, project development, sector development, and 
regional cooperation in issues and sectors consistent with ADB’s country partnership strategies 
(CPSs) for the People’s Republic of China (PRC) and Mongolia, especially those that align with 
the Sustainable Development Goals (e.g., Sustainable Development Goal 17: “Revitalize the 
global partnership for sustainable development”). 
 
2.  The TA examines regional issues in core sectors in the PRC and Mongolia that align with 
the priorities identified in the CPSs for the PRC, 2016–2020 and Mongolia, 2017–2020. “Fostering 
knowledge cooperation” and “supporting institutional and governance reform” are ADB’s strategic 
priorities in supporting the reform agenda of the Government of the PRC.2 By recognizing 
knowledge solutions as powerful catalysts for propelling development in the PRC and enhancing 
this effect, ADB continues to support a more sustainable trajectory for the PRC’s economy 
through knowledge-based solutions. The TA also aligns with ADB’s country operations business 
plan for the PRC, 2017–2019, which encourages greater synergies between the lending program, 
TA program, and knowledge work to maximize the development impact of ADB initiatives in the 
PRC.3  
 
3.  On the other hand, the CPS for Mongolia, 2017–2020 supports investments, policy 
reforms, capacity building, and knowledge sharing to sustain inclusive growth in periods of 
economic difficulty.4  To achieve this, ADB hinges its operations on three strategic pillars: (i) 
promoting economic and social stability, (ii) developing infrastructure for economic diversification, 
and  (iii)  strengthening  environmental  sustainability.  The  CPS  for  Mongolia  also  identifies 
knowledge and innovation as a cross-cutting theme, with knowledge as an integral part of ADB 
operations and innovations in projects and business procedures. ADB’s country operations 
business  plan  for  Mongolia,  2017–2019  likewise  reiterates  the  importance  of  knowledge 
operations on issues that relate to these three strategic pillars and cross-cutting themes.5  
 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
4.  Policy  research  remains  important  for  both  the  Government  of  the  PRC  and  the 
Government of Mongolia. In the PRC, policy research is recognized as a priority requiring (i) a 
better appreciation of lessons from the experience of developed economies and other middle-
income developing member countries (DMCs), and (ii) a deeper understanding of the constraints 
and conditions unique to the PRC. In Mongolia, the need for a forum in which government and 
nongovernment research institutes can discuss development constraints is evident. A deeper

appreciation of applied research methodologies could strengthen these institutes’ contribution to 
policy analysis, which is in high demand.  
 
5.  Recognizing these knowledge needs, ADB approved regional TA (RETA) 6428 on 12 
December 2007.6 Since then, this TA has served as a facility for ADB to respond quickly to 
requests from Mongolia and the PRC for knowledge products and services (KPS). The regional 
TA helped inform decisionmakers proactively on emerging strategic policy issues and disseminate 
research findings and knowledge more widely.7 The PRC’s Ministry of Finance was particularly 
satisfied with the implementation of the requested core KPS, and expressed appreciation to ADB 
during  the  country  programming  missions  and  ADB  knowledge  management  missions. 
Mongolia’s Ministry of Finance also expressed its satisfaction with the policy research and the 
logistical support given to capacity-building projects. They noted that policymakers in the Office 
of the President and the Office of the Prime Minister were using KPS outputs. 
 
6.  While the regional TA was implemented well in general, and the majority of the KPS 
subprojects were rated satisfactory, its potential has not been fully taken advantage of. Lessons 
from the earlier knowledge-oriented facility-type TA indicate the need for more systematic logistics 
support in knowledge production to (i) coordinate and communicate better both internally and 
externally to ensure the quality of knowledge products, (ii) focus on value added and impacts, and 
(iii) disseminate knowledge effectively as it is generated.8  
 
7.  The PRC and Mongolia will need continued support for policy response from lessons 
learned in other economies. Knowledge production, discussion, and dissemination involving 
relevant sector experts from academia, governments, and policy institutions will cross-fertilize 
ideas across groups and disciplines, and help disseminate outcomes to broader audiences.  
 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: effective economic policies, investment 
decisions, and project design in ADB’s DMCs increased. The TA will have the following outcome: 
the quality of policy advisory and coordination in the PRC and Mongolia improved.9  
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities  
 
9.  Output 1: Strategic, high-quality policy studies and publications on key regional 
development issues produced. The TA will produce knowledge products to formulate effective 
policy options and disseminate these in various forms to maximize the impacts of the knowledge 
products. At least five strategic policy studies on key  regional development issues will be 
published, and one regional workshop will be held. The TA will encourage close consultation with 
                                                
6 ADB. 2007. Technical Assistance for Supporting Strategic Knowledge Products and Research Networking. Manila.  
7 The TA completed seven knowledge products. Three more products are being processed, and will be published in 
2017. In addition, the TA financed various reports and logistic services, such as the translation, typesetting, and 
printing of various knowledge products.  
8 ADB. 2013. People’s Republic of China: Facility-Type Technical Assistance. Manila. This study notes that “introducing 
facility-type TA in middle-income country contexts increases goodwill for the wider ADB country portfolio. In the PRC, 
the view of knowledge as a product, and the consciousness of the costs embedded in knowledge production, enhance 
the prospects for the further development. ADB should consider formalizing a discussion on knowledge products and 
services strategy in the annual country programming review exercises.”  
9 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

3 
the governments of the PRC and Mongolia, as well as other stakeholders in ADB’s DMCs, and 
will  be  flexible  in  selecting  topics  for  policy  development  and  advisory  work  during  TA 
implementation. The criteria for considering KPS proposals will include (i) a sound understanding 
of existing knowledge in the area, ideally supported by actual achievement in the field; (ii) 
feasibility analyses of data and material availability; (iii) clear ideas of expected impacts and 
dissemination  activities;  and  (iv)  assurance  that  the  proposed  topic  is  relevant  and  has 
implications in more than one country in the region.  
 
10.  Output 2: Awareness of the findings of policy studies enhanced and disseminated. 
Completed KPS will be uploaded to the ADB website, and launched and disseminated through 
ADB events, high-level strategic policy dialogues, and conferences, in both English and local 
languages. The primary mode of dissemination is digital publication, although printed publications 
can also be used for targeted audiences (workshop participants, stakeholders with limited internet 
access, and as requested by the governments for inputs for consultations with stakeholders and 
policy inputs). The specific number of printed publications will be determined on a case-to-case 
basis. The TA will (i) build research capacity and knowledge base on issues relevant to Mongolia 
and the PRC by organizing learning forums with frontier experts; and (ii) will provide logistics 
support for high-level, knowledge-sharing events that facilitate strategic discussions of regional 
issues and policy matters facing the PRC and Mongolia, including these issues’ impact on 
neighboring countries. These high-level strategic discussions will disseminate the KPS findings 
to targeted stakeholders, with the aim of contributing to policy discussions on emerging and 
important  issues  in  Mongolia  and  the  PRC.  The  TA  will  also  provide  logistics  support  to 
departmental knowledge products such as the East Asia Department Working Paper Series, 
Observations and Suggestions Policy Briefing Note series, and Quarterly Dialogue and Update. 
The TA will also work with ADB’s Regional Knowledge Sharing Initiative program in the PRC by 
disseminating the publications and organizing the high-level discussions.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
11.  The TA is estimated to cost $625,000, of which $500,000 will be financed by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6). The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 
2. The governments will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, policy 
documents  and  guidelines,  statistical  data,  information,  office  space,  and  other  in-kind 
contributions.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
12.  ADB will administer the TA. The East Asia Department, Office of the Director General will 
select, supervise, and evaluate consultants; organize meetings; and provide staff to act as 
resource persons in the meetings. In consultation with the governments, the office, as executing 
and implementing agency, will review the proposed KPS initiatives, select KPS topics, advise on 
policy issues and research requirements, and help identify prominent scholars to carry out 
research in close consultation with experts from ADB’s relevant departments. 
 
13.  A working group will be established for each subproject consisting of experts from both 
ADB  and  relevant  external  institutions. The  working group members  will  prepare  research 
products, peer review to ensure quality of the product, and disseminate the publications. The East 
Asia Department sector divisions will be consulted on the composition of the working group and 
identification of KPS topics.

4 
14.  Consulting services. As the TA will be designed to respond and support the knowledge 
needs of the PRC and Mongolia flexibly over a 5-year period (January 2018–December 2022), 
consulting services will be determined on a case-by-case basis for each activity.10 All consultants 
will be engaged in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to 
time) and the associated project administration and TA staff instructions.11 Resource persons may 
be  engaged  to  act  as  speakers  and  reviewers  in  conferences,  workshops,  and  seminars. 
Proposals that provide honoraria to experts for KPS activities will use a competitive selection 
process acceptable to ADB whereby at least three individuals are evaluated according to their 
educational background and relevant experience. TA activities will be monitored, and reports will 
be made available through the ADB website.

IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
15.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis for 
Supporting Policy Research and Knowledge Exchange, and hereby reports this action to the 
Board.
